title: Were the Japanese as cruel in the Russo-Japanese War as they were in WWII? - Quora
tags: Military History and Wars of Japan

response.answer_text: Nope. At the time they were eager to establish their bonafides as a “civilized” nation the western nations could and should deal with as equals. For another thing the Russo-Japanese war was comparatively brief. The lengthy and frustrating war in China produced greater and greater excesses as they tried to suppress resistance. Nor had they yet instilled the fanatical military culture that came to dominate later on.

No, Japan was much more interested in establishing its status as a great power as defined by the West. Particular care was taken not only to treat Russian prisoners well, but to so military observers from a variety of nation states that the prisoners were so treated.
